{{smallcaps|noun}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|adj}}|adjective}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|num}}|numeral}} {{smallcaps|classifier}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|dem}}|demonstrative}} || these two bunches of ripe bananas |- | {{lang|km|ពួកម៉ាកខ្ញុំពីរនាក់នេះ}} || {{IPA|/puəʔmaʔ kʰɲom piː nĕə nih/}} || friend I two person[{{abbr|{{smallcaps|clf}}|classifier}}] these
{{smallcaps|noun}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|poss}}|possessive}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|num}}|numeral}} {{smallcaps|classifier}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|dem}}|demonstrative}} || these two friends of mine |- | {{lang|km|ពួកម៉ាកតូចរបស់ខ្ញុំពីរនាក់នេះ}} || {{IPA|/puəʔmaʔ touc rɔbɑh kʰɲom piː nĕə nih/}} || friend small of I two person[{{abbr|{{smallcaps|clf}}|classifier}}] these
{{smallcaps|noun}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|adj}}|adjective}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|poss}}|possessive}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|num}}|numeral}} {{smallcaps|classifier}} {{abbr|{{smallcaps|dem}}|demonstrative}} || these two small friends of mine{{rp|73}} |} The Khmer particle {{IPA|/dɑː/}} marked attributes in Old Khmer noun phrases and is used in formal and literary language to signify that what precedes is the noun and what follows is the attribute. Modern usage may carry the connotation of mild intensity.{{rp|163}} :{| style="width:25%; height:50px" | {{IPA|/ʋiəl}} || {{IPA|srae}} || {{IPA|dɑː}} || {{IPA|lʋɨŋ lʋəːj/}} |- | field || paddy || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|adj marker}}|adjective marker}} || vast |- | colspan=4 | '(very) expansive fields and paddies' |} ====Verb phrase==== Khmer verbs are completely uninflected, and once a subject or topic has been introduced or is clear from context the noun phrase may be dropped. Thus, the simplest possible sentence in Khmer consists of a single verb. For example, {{IPA|/tɨw/}} 'to go' on its own can mean "I'm going.", "He went.", "They've gone.", "Let's go.", etc.{{rp|17}} This also results in long strings of verbs such as: :{| style="width:25%; height:50px" | {{IPA|/kʰɲom}} || {{IPA|cɑng}} || {{IPA|tɨw}} || {{IPA|daə}} || {{IPA|leːng/}} |- | I || to want || to go || to walk || to play |- | colspan=5 | 'I want to go for a stroll.'{{rp|187}} |} Khmer uses three verbs for what translates into English as the copula. The general copula is {{IPA|/ciə/}}; it is used to convey identity with nominal predicates.{{rp|212}} For locative predicates, the copula is {{IPA|/nɨw/}}.{{rp|212}} The verb {{IPA|/miən/}} is the "existential" copula meaning "there is" or "there exists".{{rp|208}} :{| style="width:35%; height:50px" | {{IPA|/piəsaː}} || {{IPA|ciə}} || {{IPA|kaː}} || {{IPA|sɑmdaeŋ}} || {{IPA|cət}} || {{IPA|kumnɨt}} || {{IPA|krŏəp}} || {{IPA|jaːŋ/}} |- | language || {{smallcaps|copula}} || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|nmlz}}|nominalizer}} || to express || heart || thought || all || kind |- | colspan=8 | 'Language is the expression of all emotions and ideas' |} :{| style="text-align: left;" | {{IPA|/ʋiə}} || {{IPA|nɨw}} || {{IPA|cɪt}} || {{IPA|ʋŏət/}} || ''style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/miən}} || {{IPA|pʰaen kaː/}} |- | he || {{smallcaps|copula}} || close || temple || style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || to exist || plan |- | colspan=4 | 'He is close to the temple.' || style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || colspan=2 | 'There is a plan.' |} [[Negation]] is achieved by putting {{lang|km|មិន}} {{IPA|/mɨn/}} before the verb and the particle {{lang|km|ទេ}} {{IPA|/teː/}} at the end of the sentence or clause. In colloquial speech, verbs can also be negated without the need for a final particle, by placing {{lang|km|ឥត}} {{IPA|/ʔɑt/~/ʔət/}} before them. :{| style="text-align: left;" | {{IPA|/kʰɲom}} || {{IPA|cɨə/}} || ''style="width:15%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/kʰɲom}} || {{IPA|mɨn}} || {{IPA|cɨə}} || {{IPA|teː/}} || ''style="width:15%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/kʰɲom}} || {{IPA|ʔɑt}} || {{IPA|cɨə/}} |- | I || to believe || style="width:15%; text-align: center" |   || I || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|neg}}|negative}} || to believe || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|neg}}|negative}} || style="width:15%; text-align: center" |   || I || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|neg}}|negative}} || to believe |- | colspan=2 | 'I believe.' || style="width:15%; text-align: center" |   || colspan=4 | 'I don't believe.' || style="width:15%; text-align: center" |   || colspan=3 | 'I don't believe.' |} Past tense can be conveyed by adverbs, such as "yesterday" or by the use of perfective particles such as {{IPA|/haəj/}} :{| style="text-align: left;" | {{IPA|/kŏət}} || {{IPA|tɨw}} || {{IPA|msəlmɨɲ/}} || ''style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/kŏət}} || {{IPA|tɨw}} || {{IPA|haəj/}} |- | he || to go || yesterday || style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || he || to go || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|pfv}}|perfective}} |- | colspan=3 | 'He went yesterday.' || style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || colspan=3 | 'He left.' or 'He's already gone.'{{rp|22}} |} Different senses of future action can also be expressed by the use of adverbs like "tomorrow" or by the future tense marker {{IPA|/nɨŋ/}}, which is placed immediately before the verb, or both: :{| style="width:35%; height:50px" | {{IPA|/sʔaek}} || {{IPA|kʰɲom}} || {{IPA|nɨŋ}} || {{IPA|tɨw}} || {{IPA|saːlaː riən/}} |- | tomorrow || I || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|fut}}|future}} || to go || school |- | colspan=5 | 'Tomorrow, I will go to school.' |} [[Imperative mood|Imperatives]] are often unmarked.{{rp|240}} For example, in addition to the meanings given above, the "sentence" {{IPA|/tɨw/}} can also mean "Go!". Various words and particles may be added to the verb to soften the command to varying degrees, including to the point of politeness ([[Jussive mood|jussives]]):{{rp|240}} :{| style="text-align: left;" | {{IPA|/cou}} || {{IPA|saːk}} || {{IPA|lbɑːŋ}} || {{IPA|kʰluən}} || {{IPA|aeŋ}} || {{IPA|coh/}} || ''style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/soum}} || {{IPA|tʰʋəː}} || {{IPA|taːm}} || {{IPA|bɑndam}} || {{IPA|kŏət}} || {{IPA|tɨw/}} |- | {{abbr|{{smallcaps|imp}}|imperative}} || try || try || you || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|refl}}|reflexive}} || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|imp}}|imperative}} || style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || please || do || follow || instruction || he || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|imp}}|imperative}} |- | colspan=6 | 'Go ahead and try it yourself.' || style="width:30%; text-align: center" |   || colspan=6 | 'Please follow his instructions.' |} Prohibitives take the form "{{IPA|/kom/}} + {{smallcaps|verb}}" and also are often softened by the addition of the particle {{IPA|/ʔəj/}} to the end of the phrase.{{rp|242}} :{| style="width:35%; height:50px" | {{IPA|/kom}} || {{IPA|nɨw}} || {{IPA|tiː}} || {{IPA|nih}} || {{IPA|ʔəj/}} |- | {{abbr|{{smallcaps|proh}}|prohibitive}} || to be || place || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|dem}}|demonstrative}} || {{smallcaps|cohortative}} |- | colspan=5 | 'Don't stay in this place.' |} ====Questions==== There are three basic types of questions in Khmer.{{rp|46}} Questions requesting specific information use [[question words]]. [[Yes–no question|Polar questions]] are indicated with interrogative particles, most commonly {{IPA|/teː/}}, a homonym of the negation particle. [[Tag questions]] are indicated with various particles and rising inflection.{{rp|57}} The SVO word order is generally not [[Inversion (linguistics)|inverted]] for questions. :{| style="text-align: left;" | {{IPA|/loːk}} || {{IPA|tɨw}} || {{IPA|naː/}} || style="width:10%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/loːk}} || {{IPA|sdap}} || {{IPA|baːn}} || {{IPA|teː/}} || style="width:10%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/loːk}} || {{IPA|tɨw}} || {{IPA|psaː}} || {{IPA|haəj}} || {{IPA|rɨː}} || {{IPA|nɨw/}} |- | you || to go || where || style="width:10%; text-align: center" |   || you || understand || {{smallcaps|modal}} || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|q}}|question}} || style="width:10%; text-align: center" |   || you || to go || market || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|prf}}|perfect}} || or || yet |- | colspan=3 | 'Where are you going?' || style="width:10%; text-align: center" |   || colspan=4 | 'Can you understand?' || style="width:10%; text-align: center" |   || colspan=7 | 'Have you gone to the store yet?' |} In more formal contexts and in polite speech, questions are also marked at their beginning by the particle {{IPA|/taə/}}. :{| style="width:25%; height:50px" | {{IPA|/taə}} || {{IPA|loːk}} || {{IPA|ʔɑɲcəːɲ}} || {{IPA|tɨw}} || {{IPA|naː/}} |- | {{abbr|{{smallcaps|q}}|question}} || you || to invite || to go || where |- | colspan=5 | 'Where are you going, sir?'{{rp|302}} |} ====Passive voice==== Khmer does not have a passive voice, but there is a construction utilizing the main verb {{IPA|/trəw/}} ("to hit", "to be correct", "to affect") as an auxiliary verb meaning "to be subject to" or "to undergo"—which results in sentences that are translated to English using the passive voice.{{rp|286–288}} :{| style="width:25%; height:50px" | {{IPA|/piː}} || {{IPA|msəlmɨɲ}} || {{IPA|kʰɲom}} || {{IPA|trəw}} || {{IPA|cʰkae}} || {{IPA|kʰam/}} |- | from || yesterday || I || to undergo || dog || to bite |- | colspan=6 | 'Yesterday I was bitten by a dog.'{{rp|302}} |} ====Clause syntax==== Complex sentences are formed in Khmer by the addition of one or more [[clause]]s to the main clause. The various types of clauses in Khmer include the [[coordinate clause]], the [[relative clause]] and the [[subordinate clause]]. Word order in clauses is the same for that of the basic sentences described above. Coordinate clauses do not necessarily have to be marked; they can simply follow one another. When explicitly marked, they are joined by words similar to English conjunctions such as {{IPA|/nɨŋ/}} ("and") and {{IPA|/haəj/}} ("and then") or by clause-final conjunction-like adverbs {{IPA|/dae/}} and {{IPA|/pʰɑːŋ/}}, both of which can mean "also" or "and also"; disjunction is indicated by {{IPA|/rɨː/}} ("or").{{rp|217–218}}{{cite journal|last1=Mori|first1=K.|editor1-last=Soichi|editor1-first=I.|title=Khmer final particles ''phɔɔŋ'' & ''dae''|journal=SEALS XIII Papers from the 13th Annual Meeting of the Southeast Asian Linguistics Society 2003|date=2007|pages=139–149-6|url=http://sealang.net/sala/archives/pdf8/mori2007khmer.pdf|accessdate=6 February 2016|publisher=Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University|location=Canberra, ACT}} Relative clauses can be introduced by {{IPA|/dael/}} ("that") but, similar to coordinate clauses, often simply follow the main clause. For example, both phrases below can mean "the hospital bed that has wheels".{{rp|313}} :{| style="text-align: left;" | {{IPA|/krɛː}} || {{IPA|pɛːt}} || {{IPA|miən}} || {{IPA|kɑŋ}} || {{IPA|ruɲ/}} || style="width:20%; text-align: center" |   || {{IPA|/krɛː}} || {{IPA|pɛːt}} || {{IPA|dael}} || {{IPA|miən}} || {{IPA|kɑŋ}} || {{IPA|ruɲ/}} |- | bed || hospital || have || wheel || to push || style="width:20%; text-align: center" |   || bed || hospital || {{abbr|{{smallcaps|rel}}|relative}} || have || wheel || to push |} Relative clauses are more likely to be introduced with {{IPA|/dael/}} if they do not immediately follow the head noun.{{rp|314}} Khmer subordinate conjunctions always precede a subordinate clause.{{rp|366}} Subordinate conjunctions include words such as {{IPA|/prŭəh/}} ("because"), {{IPA|/hak bəj/}} ("seems as if") and {{IPA|/daəmbəj/}} ("in order to").{{rp|251}} ==Numerals== {{Main article|Khmer numerals}} Counting in Khmer is based on a [[biquinary]] system (the numbers from 6 to 9 have the form "five one", "five two", etc.) However, the words for multiples of ten from 30 to 90 are not related to the basic Khmer numbers, but are probably borrowed from Thai. [[Khmer numerals]], which were inherited from Indian numerals, are used more widely than [[Western Arabic numerals]]. The principal number words are listed in the following table, which gives Western and Khmer digits, Khmer spelling and IPA transcription. {| class="wikitable" | 0 | {{lang|km|០}} | {{lang|km|សូន្យ}} | {{IPA|/soun/}} | | | | |- | 1 | {{lang|km|១}} | {{lang|km|មួយ}} | {{IPA|/muəj/}} | | | | |- | 2 | {{lang|km|២}} | {{lang|km|ពីរ}} | {{IPA|/piː/}} | 20 | {{lang|km|២០}} | {{lang|km|ម្ភៃ}} | {{IPA|/məˈphɨj/}} |- | 3 | {{lang|km|៣}} | {{lang|km|បី}} | {{IPA|/ɓəːj/}} | 30 | ៣០ | {{lang|km|សាមសិប}} | {{IPA|/saːm səp/}} |- | 4 | {{lang|km|៤}} | {{lang|km|បួន}} | {{IPA|/ɓuən/}} | 40 | {{lang|km|៤០}} | {{lang|km|សែសិប}} | {{IPA|/sae səp/}} |- | 5 | {{lang|km|៥}} | {{lang|km|ប្រាំ}} | {{IPA|/pram/}} | 50 | {{lang|km|៥០}} | {{lang|km|ហាសិប}} | {{IPA|/haː səp/}} |- | 6 | {{lang|km|៦}} | {{lang|km|ប្រាំមូយ}} | {{IPA|/pram muəj/}} | 60 | {{lang|km|៦០}} | {{lang|km|ហុកសិប}} | {{IPA|/hok səp/}} |- | 7 | {{lang|km|៧}} | {{lang|km|ប្រាំពីរ}} | {{IPA|/pram piː/}}, {{IPA|/pram pɨl/}} | 70 | {{lang|km|៧០}} | {{lang|km|ចិតសិប}} | {{IPA|/cət səp/}} |- | 8 | {{lang|km|៨}} | {{lang|km|ប្រាំបី}} | {{IPA|/pram ɓəːj/}} | 80 | {{lang|km|៨០}} | {{lang|km|ប៉ែតសិប}} | {{IPA|/paet səp/}} |- | 9 | {{lang|km|៩}} | {{lang|km|ប្រាំបួន}} | {{IPA|/pram ɓuən/}} | 90 | {{lang|km|៩០}} | {{lang|km|កៅសិប}} | {{IPA|/kaʋ səp/}} |- | 10 | {{lang|km|១០}} | {{lang|km|ដប់}} | {{IPA|/ɗɑp/}} | 100 | {{lang|km|១០០}} | {{lang|km|មួយរយ}} | {{IPA|/muəj rɔːj/}} |} Intermediate numbers are formed by compounding the above elements. Powers of ten are denoted by loan words: {{lang|km|រយ}} {{IPA|/rɔːj/}} (100), {{lang|km|ពាន់}} {{IPA|/pŏən/}} (1,000), {{lang|km|ម៉ឺន}} {{IPA|/məɨn/}} (10,000), {{lang|km|សែន}} {{IPA|/saen/}} (100,000) and {{lang|km|លាន}} {{IPA|/liən/}} (1,000,000) from Thai and {{lang|km|កោដិ}} {{IPA|/kaot/}} (10,000,000) from Sanskrit.{{cite journal|last1=Jacob|first1=Judith M|title=Notes on the numerals and numeral coefficients on Old, Middle, and Modern Khmer|journal=Lingua|date=1965|volume=15|page=144|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0024384165900112|accessdate=24 January 2016|doi=10.1016/0024-3841(65)90011-2}} [[Ordinal number]]s are formed by placing the particle {{lang|km|ទី}} {{IPA|/tiː/}} before the corresponding cardinal number. ==Social registers== Khmer employs a system of [[Register (sociolinguistics)|registers]] in which the speaker must always be conscious of the social status of the person spoken to. The different registers, which include those used for common speech, polite speech, speaking to or about royals and speaking to or about monks, employ alternate verbs, names of body parts and pronouns. This results in what appears to foreigners as separate languages and, in fact, isolated villagers often are unsure how to speak with royals and royals raised completely within the court do not feel comfortable speaking the common register. As an example, the word for "to eat" used between intimates or in reference to animals is {{IPA|/siː/}}. Used in polite reference to commoners, it is {{IPA|/ɲam/}}. When used of those of higher social status, it is {{IPA|/pisa/}} or {{IPA|/tɔtuəl tiən/}}. For monks the word is {{IPA|/cʰan/}} and for royals, {{IPA|/saoj/}}. Another result is that the pronominal system is complex and full of honorific variations, just a few of which are shown in the table below. {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{IPA|[ʔuʔbaːsiʔkaː]}} |- | when addressing royalty | {{lang|km|ខ្ញុំព្រះបាទអម្ចាស់}} or {{lang|km|ទូលបង្គុំ}} (male), {{lang|km|ខ្ញុំម្ចាស់}} (female) | {{IPA|[kʰɲom preə̯̆h baːt aʔmcah]}} | {{lang|km|ព្រះករុណា}} | {{IPA|[preə̯̆h kaʔruʔnaː]}} | {{lang|km|ទ្រង់}} | {{IPA|[truə̯̆ŋ]}} |} ==Writing system== {{Main article|Khmer script}} [[File:Be Cambodian Embassy 03.jpg|thumb|right|180px|An example of modern Khmer script at the Cambodian Embassy in [[Berlin]]]] Khmer is written with the Khmer script, an [[abugida]] developed from the [[Pallava script]] of India before the 7th century when the first known inscription appeared.[http://www.omniglot.com/writing/khmer.htm Khmer Alphabet at Omniglot.com] Written left-to-right with vowel signs that can be placed after, before, above or below the consonant they follow, the Khmer script is similar in appearance and usage to [[Thai script|Thai]] and [[Lao script|Lao]], both of which were based on the Khmer system. The Khmer script is also distantly related to the [[Mon script]], the ancestor of the modern [[Burmese script]]. Within Cambodia, literacy in the Khmer alphabet is estimated at 77.6%.[http://www.un.org.kh/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=469:celebration-of-international-literacy-day-2011-supporting-cambodias-development-efforts&catid=43:latest-press-releases&Itemid=76 United Nations in Cambodia "Celebration of International Literacy Day, 2011"] Consonant symbols in Khmer are divided into two groups, or series. The first series carries the inherent vowel {{IPA|/ɑː/}} while the second series carries the inherent vowel {{IPA|/ɔː/}}. The Khmer names of the series, {{IPA|/aʔkʰosaʔ/}} ('voiceless') and {{IPA|/kʰosaʔ/}} ('voiced'), respectively, indicate that the second series consonants were used to represent the voiced phonemes of Old Khmer. As the voicing of stops was lost, however, the contrast shifted to the phonation of the attached vowels, which, in turn, evolved into a simple difference of vowel quality, often by [[Vowel breaking|diphthongization]]. This process has resulted in the Khmer alphabet having two symbols for most consonant phonemes and each vowel symbol having two possible readings, depending on the series of the initial consonant: {| |- | {{lang|km|ត}} + {{lang|km| ា}} | = {{lang|km|តា}} | {{IPA|/ta/}} | 'grandfather' |- | {{lang|km|ទ}} + {{lang|km| ា}} | = {{lang|km|ទា}} | {{IPA|/tiə/}} | 'duck' |} ==See also== {{Portal|Cambodia|Languages}} * [[Literature of Cambodia]] * [[Romanization of Khmer]] ==References and notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin}} * Ferlus, Michel.
