==Reception==
===Pre-release controversy===
To ensure that Hearst's life's influence on ''Citizen Kane'' was a secret, Welles limited access to [[dailies]] and managed the film's publicity. A December 1940 feature story in ''Stage'' magazine compared the film's narrative to ''[[Faust]]'' and made no mention of Hearst.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|111}}

The film was scheduled to premiere at RKO's flagship theater [[Radio City Music Hall]] on February 14, but in early January 1941 Welles was not finished with post-production work and told RKO that it still needed its musical score.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|205|December 2014}} Writers for national magazines had early deadlines and so a rough cut was previewed for a select few on January 3, 1941<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|111|date=April 2012}} for such magazines as ''Life'', ''Look'' and ''Redbook''. Gossip columnist [[Hedda Hopper]] (and Hollywood correspondent for Hearst papers Louella Parsons' arch rival) showed up to the screening uninvited. Most of the critics at the preview said that they liked the film and gave it good advanced reviews. Hopper wrote negatively about it, calling the film a "vicious and irresponsible attack on a great man" and criticizing its corny writing and old fashioned photography.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|205|December 2014}} ''Friday'' magazine ran an article drawing point-by-point comparisons between Kane and Hearst and documented how Welles had led on Parsons.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|111|date=April 2012}} Up until this Welles had been friendly with Parsons. The magazine quoted Welles as saying that he couldn't understand why she was so nice to him and that she should "wait until the woman finds out that the picture's about her boss." Welles immediately denied making the statement and the editor of ''Friday'' admitted that it might be false. Welles apologized to Parsons and assured her that he had never made that remark.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|205|December 2014}}

[[File:Louella-Parsons-1937.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Film columnist and Hearst employee [[Louella Parsons]] was humiliated by ''Citizen Kane'' and made numerous threats to prevent the film's release.]]
Shortly after ''Friday''{{'}}s article, Hearst sent Parsons an angry letter complaining that he had learned about ''Citizen Kane'' from Hopper and not her. The incident made a fool of Parsons and compelled her to start attacking Welles and the film. Parsons demanded a private screening of the film and personally threatened Schaefer on Hearst's behalf, first with a lawsuit and then with a vague threat of consequences for everyone in Hollywood. On January 10 Parsons and two lawyers working for Hearst were given a private screening of the film.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|206|December 2014}} James G. Stewart was present at the screening and said that she walked out of the film.<ref name="Directors in Action"/>{{Rp|11}} Soon after, Parsons called Schaefer and threatened RKO with a lawsuit if they released ''Kane''.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|111|date=April 2012}} She also contacted the management of Radio City Music Hall and demanded that they not screen it.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|206|December 2014}} The next day, the front page headline in ''Daily Variety'' read, "HEARST BANS RKO FROM PAPERS."<ref name="dailyvariety">{{cite news |title=Hearst Bans RKO From Papers |publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]]'' |date=January 10, 1941}}</ref> Hearst began this ban by suppressing promotion of RKO's ''[[Kitty Foyle (film)|Kitty Foyle]]'',<ref name="Schatz"/>{{Rp|94}} but in two weeks the ban was lifted for everything except ''Kane.''<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|111|date=April 2012}}

When Schaefer did not submit to Parsons she called other studio heads and made more threats on behalf of Hearst to expose the private lives of people throughout the entire film industry.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|206|December 2014}} Welles was threatened with an exposé about his romance with the married actress [[Dolores del Rio]], who wanted the affair kept secret until her divorce was finalized.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|207|December 2014}} In a statement to journalists Welles denied that the film was about Hearst. Hearst began preparing an injunction against the film for libel and invasion of privacy, but Welles's lawyer told him that he doubted Hearst would proceed due to the negative publicity and required testimony that an injunction would bring.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|209|December 2014}}

''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' ran a front-page story on January 13 that Hearst papers were about to run a series of editorials attacking Hollywood's practice of hiring refugees and immigrants for jobs that could be done by Americans. The goal was to put pressure on the other studios to force RKO to shelve ''Kane''.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|111|date=April 2012}} Many of those immigrants had fled Europe after the rise of fascism and feared losing the safe haven of the United States.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|209|December 2014}} Soon afterwards, Schaefer was approached by [[Nicholas Schenck]], head of [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]'s parent company, with an offer on the behalf of [[Louis B. Mayer]] and other Hollywood executives to RKO Pictures of $805,000 to destroy all prints of the film and burn the negative.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|111–112|date=April 2012}}<ref name="thomson2001">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/the-greatest-story-ever-told-sixty-years-of-citizen-kane-682857.html |last=Thomson |first=David |title=The greatest story ever told: Sixty years of Citizen Kane |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |location=London |date=April 28, 2001 |accessdate=December 26, 2009}}</ref> Once RKO's legal team reassured Schaefer, the studio announced on January 21 that ''Kane'' would be released as scheduled, and with one of the largest promotional campaigns in the studio's history. Schaefer brought Welles to New York City for a private screening of the film with the New York corporate heads of the studios and their lawyers.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|112|date=April 2012}} There was no objection to its release provided that certain changes, including the removal or softening of specific references that might offend Hearst, were made.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|112–113|date=April 2012}} Welles agreed and cut the running time from 122 minutes to 119 minutes. The cuts satisfied the corporate lawyers.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|113|date=April 2012}}

===Hearst's response===
Hearing about ''Citizen Kane'' enraged Hearst so much that he banned any advertising, reviewing, or mentioning of it in his papers, and had his journalists [[libel]] Welles.<ref name="thomson2001"/> Welles used Hearst's opposition as a pretext for previewing the film in several opinion-making screenings in Los Angeles, lobbying for its artistic worth against the hostile campaign that Hearst was waging.<ref name="thomson2001"/> A special press screening took place in early March. Henry Luce was in attendance and reportedly wanted to buy the film from RKO for $1 million to distribute it himself. The reviews for this screening were positive. A ''Hollywood Review'' headline read, "Mr. Genius Comes Through; 'Kane' Astonishing Picture". The ''Motion Picture Herald'' reported about the screening and Hearst's intention to sue RKO. ''Time'' magazine wrote that "The objection of Mr. Hearst, who founded a publishing empire on sensationalism, is ironic. For to most of the several hundred people who have seen the film at private screenings, ''Citizen Kane'' is the most sensational product of the U.S. movie industry." A second press screening occurred in April.<ref name="Schatz"/>{{Rp|94}}

When Schaefer rejected Hearst's offer to suppress the film, Hearst banned every newspaper and station in his media [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]] from reviewing—or even mentioning—the film. He also had many movie theaters ban it, and many did not show it through fear of being socially exposed by his massive newspaper empire.<ref name="Street, Sarah 1996">{{cite news |last=Street |first=Sarah |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=''History Today'' |date=March 1996}}</ref> The Oscar-nominated documentary ''[[The Battle Over Citizen Kane]]'' lays the blame for the film's relative failure squarely at the feet of Hearst. The film did decent business at the box office; it went on to be the sixth highest grossing film in its year of release, a modest success its backers found acceptable. Nevertheless, the film's commercial performance fell short of its creators' expectations.<ref name="PBS"/> Hearst's biographer David Nasaw points out that Hearst's actions were not the only reason ''Kane'' failed, however: the innovations Welles made with narrative, as well as the dark message at the heart of the film (that the pursuit of success is ultimately futile) meant that a popular audience could not appreciate its merits.<ref name="Nasaw">{{cite book |last=Nasaw |first=David |authorlink=David Nasaw |title=The Chief: The Life of William Randolph Hearst |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]] |location=Boston,MA |date=2000 |isbn=0-395-82759-0}}</ref>{{Rp|572–573|date=April 2012}}

Hearst's attacks against Welles went beyond attempting to suppress the film. Welles said that while he was on his post-filming lecture tour a police detective approached him at a restaurant and advised him not to go back to his hotel. A 14-year-old girl had reportedly been hidden in the closet of his room, and two photographers were waiting for him to walk in. Knowing he would be jailed after the resulting publicity, Welles did not return to the hotel but waited until the train left town the following morning. "But that wasn't Hearst," Welles said, "that was a hatchet man from the local Hearst paper who thought he would advance himself by doing it."<ref name="Welles TIOW"/>{{Rp|85–86}}

In March 1941 Welles directed a Broadway version of [[Richard Wright (author)|Richard Wright]]'s ''[[Native Son]]'' (and, for luck, used a "Rosebud" sled as a prop). ''[[Native Son (play)|Native Son]]'' received positive reviews, but Hearst-owned papers used the opportunity to attack Welles as a communist.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|213|December 2014}} The Hearst papers vociferously attacked Welles after his April 1941 radio play, "His Honor, the Mayor",<ref>{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/details/otr_freecompany |title=His Honor, the Mayor |publisher=Internet Archive |access-date=21 February 2016}}</ref> produced for The Free Company radio series on CBS.<ref name="Bret Wood">{{cite book |last=Wood |first=Bret  |authorlink=Bret Wood |title=Orson Welles: A Bio-Bibliography |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Westport, Connecticut |date=1990 |isbn=0-313-26538-0}}</ref>{{Rp|113}}<ref name="Wellesnet His Honor">{{cite web |url=http://www.wellesnet.com/?p=186 |title=Orson Welles defends American civil liberties in His Honor the Mayor |publisher=Wellesnet.com |date=August 4, 2007 |accessdate=December 26, 2014}}</ref>

Welles described his chance encounter with Hearst in an elevator at the [[Fairmont San Francisco|Fairmont Hotel]] on the night ''Citizen Kane'' opened in San Francisco. Hearst and Welles's father were acquaintances, so Welles introduced himself and asked Hearst if he would like to come to the opening. Hearst did not respond. "As he was getting off at his floor, I said, 'Charles Foster Kane would have accepted.' No reply", recalled Welles. "And Kane would have you know. That was his style—just as he finished Jed Leland's bad review of Susan as an opera singer."<ref name="Welles TIOW"/>{{Rp|49–50}}

In 1945 Hearst journalist Robert Shaw wrote that the film got "a full tide of insensate fury" from Hearst papers, "then it ebbed suddenly. With one brain cell working, the chief realized that such hysterical barking by the trained seals would attract too much attention to the picture. But to this day the name of Orson Welles is on the official son-of-a-bitch list of every Hearst newspaper."<ref name="Roberts">{{cite book |last=Roberts |first=Jerry |title=The Complete History of American Film Criticism |publisher=Santa Monica Press LLC |location=Santa Monica, CA |date=2010 |isbn=978-1-59580-049-7}}</ref>{{Rp|102}}

Despite Hearst's attempts to destroy the film, since 1941 references to his life and career have usually included a reference to ''Citizen Kane'', such as the headline 'Son of Citizen Kane Dies' for the obituary of Hearst's son.<ref>{{cite news |last=King |first=Susan |title=Raising 'Kane' With Hearst : An 'American Experience' Recounts the Attempts of the Publishing Magnate to Quash a Film Masterpiece |publisher=''Los Angeles Times'' |location=Los Angeles, CA |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-01-28/news/tv-29475_1_citizen-kane |date=January 28, 1996 |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref> In 2012 the Hearst estate agreed to screen the film at Hearst Castle in San Simeon, breaking Hearst's ban on the film.<ref>{{cite news |last=Chawkins |first=Steve |title=Family 'Citizen Kane' gets inside the castle |publisher=''Los Angeles Times'' |location=Los Angeles, CA |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jan/23/local/la-me-citizen-kane-20120123 |date=January 23, 2012 |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref>

===Release===
[[Radio City Music Hall]]'s management refused to screen ''Citizen Kane'' for its premiere. A possible factor was Parsons's threat that ''[[The American Weekly]]'' would run a defamatory story on the grandfather of major RKO stockholder Nelson Rockefeller.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|115|date=April 2012}} Other exhibitors feared being sued for libel by Hearst and refused to show the film.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|216|December 2014}} In March Welles threatened the RKO board of governors with a lawsuit if they did not release the film. Schaefer stood by Welles and opposed the board of governors.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|210|December 2014}} When RKO still delayed the film's release Welles offered to buy the film for $1 million and the studio finally agreed to release the film on May 1.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|215|December 2014}}

Schaefer managed to book a few theaters willing to show the film. Hearst papers refused to accept advertising.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|115|date=April 2012}} RKO's publicity advertisements for the film erroneously promoted it as a love story.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|217|December 2014}}

''Kane'' opened at the [[Palace Theatre (New York City)|RKO Palace Theatre]] on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] in New York on May 1, 1941,<ref name="AFIcat"/> in Chicago on May 6, and in Los Angeles on May 8.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|115|date=April 2012}} Welles said that at the Chicago premiere that he attended the theater was almost empty.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|216|December 2014}} It did well in cities and larger towns but fared poorly in more remote areas. RKO still had problems getting exhibitors to show the film. For example, one chain controlling more than 500 theaters got Welles's film as part of a package but refused to play it, reportedly out of fear of Hearst.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|117|date=April 2012}} Hearst's disruption of the film's release damaged its box office performance and, as a result, it lost $160,000 during its initial run.<ref name="Jewell">{{cite book |last1=Jewell |first1=Richard B. |last2=Harbin |first2=Vernon |title=The RKO Story |publisher=[[Arlington House Publishers]]/[[Crown Publishing Group]] |location=New York |date=1982 |isbn=978-0-517-54656-7}}</ref>{{Rp|164|date=April 2012}}<ref name="rko">{{cite news |last=Jewell |first=Richard |title=RKO Film Grosses: 1931–1951 |publisher=''Historical Journal of Film Radio and Television'', Vol 14 No 1 |date=1994 |page=45}}</ref> The film earned $23,878 during its first week in New York. By the ninth week it only made $7,279. Overall it lost money in New York, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington, D.C., but made a profit in Seattle.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|216|December 2014}}

===Contemporary responses===
''Citizen Kane'' received good reviews from several critics. ''[[New York Daily News]]'' critic Kate Cameron called it "one of the most interesting and technically superior films that has ever come out of a Hollywood studio".<ref name="Cameron">{{cite news |last=Cameron |first=Kate |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=''[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily-News]]'' |date=May 2, 1941}}</ref> ''[[New York World-Telegram]]'' critic William Boehnel said that the film was "staggering and belongs at once among the greatest screen achievements".<ref name="Boehnel">{{cite news |last=Boehnel |first=William |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=''[[New York World-Telegram]]'' |date=May 2, 1941}}</ref> ''Time'' magazine wrote that "it has found important new techniques in picture-making and story-telling."<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|211|December 2014}} ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine's review said that "few movies have ever come from Hollywood with such powerful narrative, such original technique, such exciting photography."<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|211|December 2014}} [[John Mosher (writer)|John C. Mosher]] of ''The New Yorker'' called the film's style "like fresh air" and raved "Something new has come to the movie world at last."<ref name="Roberts"/>{{Rp|68}} Anthony Bower of ''[[The Nation]]'' called it "brilliant" and praised the cinematography and performances by Welles, Comingore and Cotten.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bower |first=Anthony |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=[[The Nation]] |location=New York |date=April 26, 1941}}</ref> [[John O'Hara]]'s ''[[Newsweek]]'' review called it the best picture he'd ever seen and said Welles was "the best actor in the history of acting."<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|211|December 2014}} Welles called O'Hara's review "the greatest review that anybody ever had."<ref name="Lunches"/>{{Rp|100}}

The day following the premiere of ''Citizen Kane,'' ''[[The New York Times]]'' critic [[Bosley Crowther]] wrote that "... it comes close to being the most sensational film ever made in Hollywood."

<blockquote>Count on Mr. Welles: he doesn't do things by halves. ... Upon the screen he discovered an area large enough for his expansive whims to have free play. And the consequence is that he has made a picture of tremendous and overpowering scope, not in physical extent so much as in its rapid and graphic rotation of thoughts. Mr. Welles has put upon the screen a motion picture that really moves.<ref>{{cite news |last=Crowther |first=Bosley |authorlink=Bosley Crowther |title=Orson Welles's Controversial 'Citizen Kane' Proves a Sensational Film at Palace |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=May 2, 1941}}</ref></blockquote>

In the UK [[C. A. Lejeune]] of ''[[The Observer]]'' called it "The most exciting film that has come out of Hollywood in twenty-five years"<ref>{{cite news |last=Lejeune |first=C. A. |authorlink=C. A. Lejeune |title=The most exciting film that has come out of Hollywood in twenty-five years |publisher=''[[The Observer]]'' |location=London, UK |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/1941/oct/12/derekmalcolmscenturyoffilm |date=October 12, 1941 |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref> and [[Dilys Powell]] of ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' said the film's style was made "with the ease and boldness and resource of one who controls and is not controlled by his medium."<ref name=Heylin>{{cite book |last=Heylin |first=Clinton |authorlink=Clinton Heylin |title=Despite the System: Orson Welles Versus the Hollywood Studios |publisher=[[Chicago Review Press]] |location=Chicago, Illinois |year=2006 |isbn=978-1-55652-547-6}}</ref>{{Rp|63|December 2014}} [[Edward Tangye Lean]] of ''[[Horizon (magazine)|Horizon]]'' praised the film's  technical style, calling it "perhaps a decade ahead of its contemporaries."<ref>{{cite news |last=Lean |first=Tangye |authorlink=Edward Tangye Lean |title=Pre-War Citizen |publisher=''[[Horizon (magazine)|Horizon]]'' |location=London, UK |date=November 1941}}</ref>{{efn|Kevin Brownlow believes that Lean's brother [[David Lean|David]] was influential on (if not co-writer of) this review. Years later Welles thanked David Lean for the article.<ref>{{cite book|last=Brownlow |first=Kevin |authorlink=Kevin Brownlow |title=David Lean: A Biography |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]] |location=London, UK |date=1996 |isbn= 978-1-4668-3237-4 }}</ref>{{Rp|notes }}}}

A few reviews were mixed. [[Otis Ferguson]] of ''[[The New Republic]]'' said it was "the boldest free-hand stroke in major screen production since [[D.W. Griffith|Griffith]] and [[Billy Bitzer|Bitzer]] were running wild to unshackle the camera", but also criticized its style, calling it a "retrogression in film technique" and stating that "it holds no great place" in film history.<ref name="Ferguson">{{cite news |last=Ferguson |first=Otis |authorlink=Otis Ferguson |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=''[[The New Republic]]'' |date=June 2, 1941}}</ref> Ferguson reacted to some of the film's celebrated visual techniques by calling them "just willful dabbling" and "the old shell game." In a rare film review, filmmaker [[Erich von Stroheim]] criticized the film's story and non-linear structure, but praised the technical style and performances, and wrote "Whatever the truth may be about it, ''Citizen Kane'' is a great picture and will go down in screen history. More power to Welles!"<ref>{{cite news |last=von Stroheim |first=Erich |authorlink=Erich von Stroheim |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=''Decision, a review of free culture'', Volume 1, number 6 |url=http://www.fredcamper.com/M/VonStroheim.html |date=June 6, 1941 |accessdate=December 16, 2014 |pages=91–93}}</ref>

Some prominent critics wrote negative reviews. In his 1941 review for ''[[Sur (magazine)|Sur]]'', [[Jorge Luis Borges]] famously called the film "a labyrinth with no center" and predicted that its legacy would be a film "whose historical value is undeniable but which no one cares to see again."<ref name="Borges">{{cite news |last=Borges |first=Jorge Luis |authorlink=Jorge Luis Borges |title=El Ciudadano |publisher=''[[Sur (magazine)|Sur]]'', Number 83 |location=Buenos Aires, Argentina |url=http://www.canaltrans.com/lalinternamagica/005.html |date=August 1941 |accessdate=December 7, 2014}}</ref> ''[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus Weekend Magazine]]'' critic Erle Cox called the film "amazing" but thought that Welles's break with Hollywood traditions was "overdone."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article8231805 |last=Cox |first=Erle |authorlink=Erle Cox |title=Screen Realism May Be a Little Too Real |publisher=''[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus Weekend Magazine]]'' |location=Melbourne, Australia |date=February 7, 1942 |page=6}}</ref> ''[[Tatler]]''{{'}}s [[James Agate]] called it "the well-intentioned, muddled, amateurish thing one expects from high-brows"<ref>{{cite news |last=Agate |first=James |authorlink=James Agate |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=''[[Tatler (1901)|The Tatler]]'', reprinted in ''Around Cinemas'' (1946) Home & Van Thal Ltd. |date=October 22, 1941 |pages=227–229}}</ref> and "a quite good film which tries to run the psychological essay in harness with your detective thriller, and doesn't quite succeed."<ref>{{cite news |last=Agate |first=James |title=More About Citizen Kane |publisher=''[[Tatler (1901)|The Tatler]]'', reprinted in ''Around Cinemas'' (1946) Home & Van Thal Ltd. |date=November 5, 1941 |pages=229–231}}</ref> Eileen Creelman of ''[[The Sun (New York)|The New York Sun]]'' called it "a cold picture, unemotional, a puzzle rather than a drama".<ref name="Higham"/>{{Rp|178}} Other people who disliked the film were [[W. H. Auden]]<ref name="Lunches"/>{{Rp|98}} and [[James Agee]].<ref name= "Lunches"/>{{Rp|99}} After watching the film on the 29th January 1942 [[Kenneth Williams]], then aged 15, writing in his first diary curtly described it as "boshey rot".<ref>{{cite book |last=Davies |first=Russell |date=1993 |title=The Kenneth Williams Diaries |publisher=Harper Collins |page=2 |isbn=0-00-638090-5 }}</ref> Bosh meaning empty or meaningless, nonsense or foolish.

===Awards===
[[File:Citizen-Kane-Welles-Coulouris.jpg|thumb|right|The [[National Board of Review]] recognized both Welles and [[George Coulouris]] for their performances in ''Citizen Kane'' (1941), which was also voted the year's best film.]]
''Citizen Kane'' received the [[1941 New York Film Critics Circle Awards|New York Film Critics Circle Award]] for Best Picture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nyfcc.com/awards/?awardyear=1941 |title=1941 Awards |publisher=[[New York Film Critics Circle]] |accessdate=February 23, 2016}}</ref> The [[National Board of Review]] voted it Best Film of 1941,<ref>{{Cite journal |last= |first= |date=January 1942 |title=Ten Best 1941 |url=https://archive.org/stream/nationalboardofr1415nati#page/4/mode/1up |magazine=National Board of Review Magazine |location= |publisher=[[National Board of Review]] |volume=XVII |issue=1 |page=4 |access-date=February 23, 2016 }}</ref> and recognized Welles and Coulouris for their performances.<ref>{{Cite journal |last= |first= |date=January 1942 |title=Ten Best 1941 |url=https://archive.org/stream/nationalboardofr1415nati#page/6/mode/1up |magazine=National Board of Review Magazine |location= |publisher=[[National Board of Review]] |volume=XVII |issue=1 |page=6 |access-date=February 23, 2016 }}</ref>

''Citizen Kane'' received nine nominations at the [[14th Academy Awards|1941 Academy Awards]]:<ref name="Oscars1942">{{cite web |url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1942 |title=The 14th Academy Awards (1942) Nominees and Winners |publisher=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science |accessdate=November 29, 2014}}</ref>
* [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Outstanding Motion Picture]] – [[Mercury Theatre|Mercury]]
* [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] – [[Orson Welles]]
* [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] – Orson Welles
* [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Writing (Original Screenplay)]] – [[Herman J. Mankiewicz]], Orson Welles
* [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Art Direction (Black-and-White)]] – [[Perry Ferguson]], [[Van Nest Polglase]], [[A. Roland Fields|Al Fields]], [[Darrell Silvera]]
* [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography (Black-and-White)]] – [[Gregg Toland]]

It was widely believed the film would win most of its Oscar nominations, but it received only the award for Best Writing (Original Screenplay), shared by Welles and Mankiewicz. ''Variety'' reported that block voting by screen extras deprived ''Citizen Kane'' of Academy Awards for Best Picture and Best Actor (Welles), and similar prejudices were likely to have been responsible for the film receiving no technical awards.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|117}}<ref>{{Cite journal |last= |first= |date=March 4, 1942 |title=Extras Scuttled Welles |url=https://archive.org/stream/variety145-1942-03#page/n3/mode/1up |magazine=Variety |location= |publisher= |access-date=February 23, 2016 }}</ref>

==Legacy==
''Citizen Kane'' was the only film made under Welles's original contract with RKO Pictures, which gave him complete creative control.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|223}} Welles's new business manager and attorney permitted the contract to lapse. In July 1941,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wellesnet.com/jack-moss-the-man-who-ruined-welles/ |title=Jack Moss: The Man Who Ruined Welles? |last=Wilson |first=Jeff  |date=November 29, 2006 |website=Wellesnet |publisher= |access-date=April 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wellesnet.com/orson-welless-the-magnificent-ambersons-turns-70-triumph-or-tragedy/ |title=The Memos—Orson Welles' ''The Magnificent Ambersons'' turns 70: Triumph or Tragedy? |last=French |first=Lawrence  |date=March 2, 2012 |website=Wellesnet |access-date=April 12, 2016}}</ref> Welles reluctantly signed a new and less favorable deal with RKO<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|223}} under which he produced and directed ''[[The Magnificent Ambersons (film)|The Magnificent Ambersons]]'' (1942), produced ''[[Journey into Fear (1943 film)|Journey into Fear]]'' (1943), and began ''[[It's All True (film)|It's All True]]'', a film he agreed to do without payment. In the new contract Welles was an employee of the studio<ref>{{cite news |last=Brady |first=Thomas |date=November 16, 1941 |title=Genius Under Stress: Spending RKO's Money Worries Orson Welles |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1941/11/16/archives/spending-rkos-money-worries-orson-welles-four-on-the-road-back.html |newspaper=The New York Times  |access-date=April 12, 2016 }}</ref> and lost the right to final cut, which later allowed RKO to modify and re-cut ''The Magnificent Ambersons'' over his objections.<ref name="Leaming OW"/>{{Rp|223}} In June 1942 Schaefer resigned the presidency of RKO Pictures and Welles's contract was terminated by [[Charles Koerner|his successor]].<ref name="Wellesnet Memos"/>

===Release in Europe===
During [[World War II]], ''Citizen Kane'' was not seen in most European countries. It was shown in France for the first time on July 10, 1946 at the Marbeuf theatre in Paris.<ref name=Truffaut>{{cite book |last1=de Baecque |first1=Antoine |last2=Toubiana |first2=Serge |title=Truffaut: A Biography |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley & Los Angeles, CA |date=1999 |isbn=978-0-520-22524-4}}</ref>{{Rp|34–35}}{{efn|871,261 admissions<ref name="france">[http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&rurl=translate.google.com.au&u=http://www.boxofficestory.com/box-office-orson-welles-c25320542&usg=ALkJrhhxH2PrC9aZtsMZPjsNZBUe3iaBhw Orson Welles box office information in France] at Box Office Story</ref>}} Initially  most French film critics were influenced by the negative reviews of [[Jean-Paul Sartre]] in 1945 and Georges Sadoul in 1946.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|118}} At that time many French intellectuals and filmmakers shared Sartre's negative opinion that Hollywood filmmakers were uncultured.<ref name=Andrew>{{cite book |last=Andrew |first=Dudley |authorlink=Dudley Andrew |title=André Bazin |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=New York,NY |date=1978 |isbn=978-0-231-07399-8}}</ref>{{Rp|124}} Sartre criticized the film's flashbacks for its nostalgic and romantic preoccupation with the past instead of the realities of the present and said that "the whole film is based on a misconception of what cinema is all about. The film is in the past tense, whereas we all know that cinema has got to be in the present tense."<ref>{{cite news |last=Sartre |first=Jean-Paul |authorlink=Jean-Paul Sartre |title=Quand Hollywood veut faire penser: 'Citizen Kane' film d'Orson Welles |publisher=''L'Ecran francais'', number 5 |location=Paris, France |date=August 1, 1945 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2014/08/12/sartre-and-borges-on-welles/ |last=Piepenbring |first=Dan |title=Sartre and Borges on Welles |publisher=''[[The Paris Review]]'' |location=Paris, France |date=August 12, 2014 |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref>

[[André Bazin]], a little-known film critic working for Sartre's ''[[Les Temps modernes]]'', was asked to give an [[Impromptu speaking|impromptu speech]] about the film after a screening at the Colisée Theatre in the autumn of 1946<ref name=Truffaut/>{{Rp|36}} and changed the opinion of much of the audience. This speech led to Bazin's 1947 article "The Technique of Citizen Kane",<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|125}} which directly influenced public opinion about the film.<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|124}} Carringer wrote that Bazin was "the one who did the most to enhance the film's reputation."<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|118}}{{efn|Bordwell has hypothesized that Bazin was influenced by publicity about the film's innovations that were published in France during its first release. These included interviews by Welles and the publication of Toland's article "The Motion Picture Cameraman" in the January 1947 issue of ''La Revue du Cinéma''. Bordwell believes that Bazin was aware of the legend of film's innovations before having seen it.<ref name="Minding"/>{{Rp|72–73}}}} Both Bazin's critique of the film and his theories about cinema itself centered around his strong belief in [[mise en scène]]. These theories were diametrically opposed to both the popular [[Soviet montage theory]]<ref name=BazinatWork/>{{Rp|xiii}} and the politically [[Marxist]] and anti-Hollywood beliefs of most French film critics at that time.<ref name=Truffaut/>{{Rp|36}} Bazin believed that a film should depict reality without the filmmaker imposing their "will" on the spectator, which the Soviet theory supported.<ref name=BazinatWork/>{{Rp|xiii}} Bazin wrote that ''Citizen Kane''{{'}}s mise en scène created a "new conception of filmmaking"<ref name=BazinatWork/>{{Rp|233}} and that the freedom given to the audience from the deep focus shots was innovative by changing the entire concept of the cinematic image.<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|128}} Bazin wrote extensively about the mise en scène in the scene where Susan Alexander attempts suicide, which was one long take while other films would have used four or five shots in the scene.<ref name=BazinatWork/>{{Rp|234}} Bazin wrote that the film's mise en scène "forces the spectator to participate in the meaning of the film"  and creates "a psychological realism which brings the spectator back to the real conditions of perception."<ref name="Minding"/>{{Rp|72}}

In his 1950 essay "The Evolution of the Language of Cinema", Bazin placed ''Citizen Kane'' center stage as a work which ushered in a new period in cinema.<ref name=WIC>{{cite book |last=Bazin |first=André |author-link=André Bazin |translator-last=Gray |translator-first=Hugh |orig-year=1950 |chapter=The Evolution of the Language of Cinema |chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/Bazin_Andre_What_Is_Cinema_Volume_1#page/n32/mode/1up |title=What is Cinema? |publisher=University of California Press |location=Oakland, CA |publication-date=1967 |pages=23–40 |isbn=978-0-520-24227-2}}</ref>{{Rp|37}} One of the first critics to defend motion pictures as being on the same artistic level as literature or painting, Bazin often used the film as an example of cinema as an art form<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|129}} and wrote that "Welles has given the cinema a theoretical restoration. He has enriched his filmic repertory with new or forgotten effects that, in today's artistic context, take on a significance we didn't know they could have."<ref name=BazinatWork/>{{Rp|236}} Bazin also compared the film to [[Roberto Rossellini]]'s ''[[Paisà]]'' for having "the same aesthetic concept of realism"<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|117–118}} and to the films of [[William Wyler]] shot by Toland (such as ''[[The Little Foxes (film)|The Little Foxes]]'' and ''The Best Years of Our Lives''), all of which used deep focus cinematography that Bazin called "a dialectical step forward in film language."<ref name="Minding"/>{{Rp|71}}

Bazin's praise of the film went beyond film theory and reflected his own philosophy towards life itself.<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|125}} His metaphysical interpretations about the film reflected humankind's place in the universe.<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|128}} Bazin believed that the film examined one person's identity and search for meaning. It portrayed the world as ambiguous and full of contradictions, whereas films up until then simply portrayed people's actions and motivations.<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|130}} Bazin's biographer [[Dudley Andrew]] wrote that:

<blockquote>The world of ''Citizen Kane'', that mysterious, dark, and infinitely deep world of space and memory where voices trail off into distant echoes and where meaning dissolves into interpretation, seemed to Bazin to mark the starting point from which all of us try to construct provisionally the sense of our lives.<ref name=Andrew/>{{Rp|129}}</blockquote>

Bazin went on to co-found ''[[Cahiers du cinéma]]'', whose contributors (including future film directors François Truffaut and [[Jean-Luc Godard]]) also praised the film.<ref name=WIC/>{{Rp|37}} The popularity of Truffaut's [[auteur theory]] helped the film's and Welles's reputation.<ref name="Bordwell Thompson">{{cite book |last1=Bordwell |first1=David |authorlink1=David Bordwell |last2=Thompson |first2=Kristin |authorlink2=Kristin Thompson |title=Film History: An Introduction |publisher=McGraw-Hill inc. |location=New York |date=1994 |isbn=978-0-07-338613-3}}</ref>{{Rp|263}}

===Re-evaluation===
By 1942 ''Citizen Kane'' had run its course theatrically and, apart from a few showings at big city arthouse cinemas, it largely vanished and both the film's and Welles's reputation fell among American critics. In 1949 critic Richard Griffith in his overview of cinema, ''The Film Till Now'', dismissed ''Citizen Kane'' as "... tinpot if not crackpot [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]]."<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|117–118|date=April 2012}}

In the United States, it was neglected and forgotten until its revival on television in the mid-1950s. Three key events in 1956 led to its re-evaluation in the United States: first, RKO was one of the first studios to sell its library to television, and early that year ''Citizen Kane'' started to appear on television; second, the film was re-released theatrically to coincide with Welles's return to the New York stage, where he played ''[[King Lear]]''; and third, American film critic Andrew Sarris wrote "Citizen Kane: The American Baroque" for ''[[Film Culture]]'', and described it as "the great American film" and "the work that influenced the cinema more profoundly than any American film since ''[[Birth of a Nation]]''."<ref name="Sarris">{{cite news |last=Sarris |first=Andrew |authorlink=Andrew Sarris |title=Citizen Kane: The American Baroque |publisher=''[[Film Culture]]'', number 9 |year=1956 |accessdate=}}</ref> Carringer considers Sarris's essay as the most important influence on the film's reputation in the US.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|119}}

During [[Expo 58]], a poll of over 100 film historians named ''Kane'' one of the top ten greatest films ever made (the group gave first-place honors to ''[[The Battleship Potemkin]]''). When a group of young film directors announced their vote for the top six, they were booed for not including the film.<ref name=empire>{{cite news |last1=Newman |first1=Kim |authorlink1=Kim Newman |last2=Freer |first2=Ian |authorlink2=Ian Freer |last3=Fraser |first3=Rob |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' |date=July 2003 |accessdate= |pages=146–156}}</ref>{{Rp|152}}

In the decades since, its critical status as [[films that have been considered the greatest ever|the greatest film ever made]] has grown, with numerous essays and books on it including Peter Cowie's ''The Cinema of Orson Welles'', Ronald Gottesman's ''Focus on Citizen Kane'', a collection of significant reviews and background pieces, and most notably Kael's essay, "Raising Kane", which promoted the value of the film to a much wider audience than it had reached before.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|120|date=April 2012}} Despite its criticism of Welles, it further popularized the notion of ''Citizen Kane'' as the great American film. The rise of art house and film society circuits also aided in the film's rediscovery.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|119|date=April 2012}} David Thomson said that the film 'grows with every year as America comes to resemble it."<ref name="Wakeman"/>{{Rp|1172}}

''Citizen Kane'' has been called the most influential film of all time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tiff.net/cinematheque/orsonwelleslostandfound/citizen-kane |last=Quandt |first=James |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=[[Toronto International Film Festival]] |location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada |date=2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107075132/http://tiff.net/cinematheque/orsonwelleslostandfound/citizen-kane |archive-date=January 7, 2015 |accessdate=May 29, 2015}}</ref> [[Richard Corliss]] has asserted that [[Jules Dassin]]'s 1941 film ''[[The Tell-Tale Heart (1941 film)|The Tell-Tale Heart]]'' was the first example of its influence<ref>{{cite news |last=Corliss |first=Richard |title=Master of the Heist |publisher=''Time'' |location=New York,NY |url=http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1728260,00.html |date=April 6, 2008 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> and the first [[popular culture|pop culture]] [[Intertextuality|reference]] to the film occurred later in 1941 when the [[Spoof film|spoof]] comedy ''[[Hellzapoppin' (film)|Hellzapoppin']]'' featured a "Rosebud" sled.<ref>{{cite news |last=Strauss |first=Theodore |title=Hellzapoppin' (1941)  |publisher=''The New York Times'' |location=New York, NY |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/94794/Hellzapoppin-/overview |date=December 26, 1941 |accessdate=January 6, 2015}}</ref>{{efn|Another early pop culture reference occurred in Welles's ''The Magnificent Ambersons'', which includes a brief glimpse of a newspaper article written by "Jed Leland".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.davidbordwell.net/blog/2014/05/30/the-magnificent-ambersons-a-usable-past/ |last=Bordwell |first=David |title=The Magnificent Ambersons: A usable past |date=May 30, 2014 |accessdate=January 6, 2015}}</ref>}} The film's cinematography was almost immediately influential and in 1942 ''[[American Cinematographer]]'' wrote "without a doubt the most immediately noticeable trend in cinematography methods during the year was the trend toward crisper definition and increased depth of field."<ref name=Richardson>{{cite book |last=Richardson |first=Carl |title=Autopsy: An Element of Realism in Film Noir |publisher=[[Scarecrow Press]] |location=Lanham, MD |date=1992 |isbn= 978-0-8108-2496-6}}</ref>{{Rp|51}}

The cinematography influenced [[John Huston]]'s ''[[The Maltese Falcon (1941 film)|The Maltese Falcon]]''. Cinematographer [[Arthur Edeson]] used a wider-angle lens than Toland and the film includes many long takes, low angles and shots of the ceiling, but it did not use deep focus shots on large sets to the extent that ''Citizen Kane'' did. Edeson and Toland are often credited together for revolutionizing cinematography in 1941.<ref name=Richardson/>{{Rp|48–50}} Toland's cinematography influenced his own work on ''[[The Best Years of Our Lives]]''. Other films influenced include ''[[Gaslight (1944 film)|Gaslight]]'', ''[[Mildred Pierce (film)|Mildred Pierce]]'' and ''[[Jane Eyre (1943 film)|Jane Eyre]]''.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|85–86}} Cinematographer [[Kazuo Miyagawa]] said that his use of deep focus was influenced by "the camera work of Gregg Toland in ''Citizen Kane''" and not by traditional Japanese art.<ref>{{cite news |last=Buruma |first=Ian |title=The Beauty in Her Sacrifice |publisher=The New York Review of Books |location=New York, NY |url=http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2014/may/06/mizoguchi-beauty-sacrifice/ |date=May 6, 2014 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref>

Its cinematography, lighting, and flashback structure influenced such [[film noir]]s of the 1940s and 1950s as ''[[The Killers (1946 film)|The Killers]]'', ''[[Keeper of the Flame (film)|Keeper of the Flame]]'', ''[[Caught (1949 film)|Caught]]'', ''[[The Great Man]]''<ref name="Cook"/>{{Rp|425}} and ''[[This Gun for Hire]]''.<ref name="Carringer TMOCK"/>{{Rp|85–86}} David Bordwell and [[Kristin Thompson]] have written that "For over a decade thereafter American films displayed exaggerated foregrounds and somber lighting, enhanced by long takes and exaggerated camera movements." However, by the 1960s filmmakers such as those from the French New Wave and [[Cinéma vérité]] movements favored "flatter, more shallow images with softer focus" and ''Citizen Kane''{{'}}s style became less fashionable. American filmmakers in the 1970s combined these two approaches by using long takes, rapid cutting, deep focus and telephoto shots all at once.<ref name="Bordwell Thompson"/>{{Rp|798}} Its use of long takes influenced films such as ''[[The Asphalt Jungle]]'', and its use of deep focus cinematography influenced ''[[Gun Crazy]]'',<ref name="Bordwell Thompson"/>{{Rp|389–390}} ''[[The Whip Hand]]'', ''[[The Devil's General]]'' and ''[[Justice Is Done]]''.<ref name="Bordwell Thompson"/>{{Rp|414}} The flashback structure in which different characters have conflicting versions of past events influenced ''[[La commare secca]]''<ref name="Bordwell Thompson"/>{{Rp|533}} and ''[[Man of Marble]]''.<ref name="Bordwell Thompson"/>{{Rp|747}}

The film's structure influenced the biographical films ''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]'' and ''[[Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters]]''—which begin with the subject's death and show their life in flashbacks—as well as Welles's thriller ''[[Mr. Arkadin]]''.<ref name=empire/>{{Rp|154}} Rosenbaum sees similarities in the film's plot to ''Mr. Arkadin'', as well as the theme of nostalgia for loss of innocence throughout Welles's career, beginning with ''Citizen Kane'' and including ''The Magnificent Ambersons'', ''Mr. Arkadin'' and ''[[Chimes at Midnight]]''. Rosenbaum also points out how the film influenced [[Warren Beatty]]'s ''[[Reds (film)|Reds]]''. The film depicts the life of Jack Reed through the eyes of Louise Bryant, much as Kane's life is seen through the eyes of Thompson and the people who he interviews. Rosenbaum also compared the romantic montage between Reed and Bryant with the breakfast table montage in ''Citizen Kane''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Rosenbaum |first=Jonathan |title=Movies as Politics |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley and Los Angeles |date=1997 |isbn=978-0-520-20615-1}}</ref>{{Rp|113–116, 300–302}}

[[Akira Kurosawa]]'s ''[[Rashomon]]'' is often compared to the film due to both having complicated plot structures told by multiple characters in the film. Welles said his initial idea for the film was "Basically, the idea ''Rashomon'' used later on,"<ref name="Welles TIOW"/>{{Rp|53}} however Kurosawa had not yet seen the film before making ''Rashomon'' in 1950.<ref>{{cite book |last=Richie |first=Donald |title=The Films of Akira Kurosawa |publisher=University of California Press |location=Oakland, CA |date=1998 |isbn=978-0-520-22037-9}}</ref>{{Rp|78}} [[Nigel Andrews]] has compared the film's complex plot structure to ''Rashomon'', ''[[Last Year at Marienbad]]'', ''[[Memento (film)|Memento]]'' and ''[[Magnolia (film)|Magnolia]]''. Andrews also compares Charles Foster Kane to [[Michael Corleone]] in ''[[The Godfather (film series)|The Godfather]]'', [[Jake LaMotta]] in ''[[Raging Bull]]'' and Daniel Plainview in ''[[There Will Be Blood]]'' for their portrayals of "haunted megalomaniac[s], presiding over the shards of [their] own [lives]."<ref>{{cite news |last=Andrews |first=Nigel |authorlink=Nigel Andrews |title=The Mark of Kane. Orson Welles' masterpiece, 70 years on |publisher=''[[Financial Times]]'' |location=London, UK |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/life/ft/2011/05/the_mark_of_kane.html |date=May 8, 2011 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref>

The films of [[Paul Thomas Anderson]] have been compared to it. ''Variety'' compared ''There Will Be Blood'' to the film<ref>{{cite news |last=McCarthy |first=Todd |title=Review 'There Will Be Blood' |publisher=''Variety'' |location=Los Angeles, CA |url=https://variety.com/2007/film/reviews/there-will-be-blood-4-1200554877/ |date=November 1, 2007 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> and called it "one that rivals ''[[Giant (1956 film)|Giant]]'' and ''Citizen Kane'' in our popular lore as origin stories about how we came to be the people we are."<ref>{{cite news |title=Oscars 2007: 'There Will Be Blood' = 'Citizen Kane'? |publisher=''Los Angeles Times'' |location=Los Angeles |url=http://goldderby.latimes.com/awards_goldderby/2007/09/there-will-be-b.html |date=September 28, 2007 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Master (2012 film)|The Master]]'' has been called "movieland's only spiritual sequel to ''Citizen Kane'' that doesn't shrivel under the hefty comparison"<ref>{{cite web |last=Carson |first=Tom |title=A Golden State: Paul Thomas Anderson's Secret, Sprawling, Multi-Film History of California |publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures |url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/paul-thomas-anderson-inherant-vice-magnolia-boogie-nights-california-history/ |date=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> and the film's loose depiction of [[L. Ron Hubbard]] has been compared to ''Citizen Kane''{{'}}s depiction of Hearst.<ref>{{cite news |last=Tookey |first=Chris |title=A cult classic? Never! Based on the story of Scientology, The Master is topped for Oscar glory ... but Chris Tookey refuses to be brainwashed |publisher=''The Daily Mail'' |location=London, UK |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2226594/The-Master-movie-review-The-Scientology-story--CHRIS-TOOKEY-refuses-brainwashed.html |date=November 2, 2012 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Social Network]]'' has been compared to the film for its depiction of a media mogul and by the character Erica Albright being similar to "Rosebud".<ref>{{cite news |last=Meyers |first=Jeff |title=The Social Network: Feeding frenzy: Or the portrait of a Facebook's billionaire asshole as a younger man |publisher=Detroit Metro Times |location=Detroit, MI |url=http://www.metrotimes.com/detroit/the-social-network/Content?oid=2163535 |date=October 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 6, 2015}}</ref> The controversy of the [[Sony Pictures Entertainment hack|Sony hacking]] before the release of ''[[The Interview]]'' brought comparisons of Hearst's attempt to suppress the film.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rosenthal |first=Phil |title=Sony hacks: Rogen, Franco could learn from Welles, 'Citizen Kane' |publisher=''The Chicago Tribune'' |location=Chicago, Illinois |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/columnists/ct-rosenthal-sony-hack-citizen-kane-1219-biz-20141220-column.html#page=1 |date=December 19, 2014 |accessdate=January 6, 2015}}</ref> The film's plot structure and some specific shots influenced [[Todd Haynes]]'s ''[[Velvet Goldmine]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ebert |first=Roger |title=Velvet Goldmine |publisher=rogerebert.com |location=Chicago, Illinois |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/velvet-goldmine-1998 |date=November 6, 1998 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> [[Abbas Kiarostami]]'s ''[[The Traveler (1974 film)|The Traveler]]'' has been called "the ''Citizen Kane'' of the Iranian children's cinema."<ref>{{cite web |last=Rist |first=Peter |title=Meeting Abbas Kiarostami |url=http://offscreen.com/view/kiarostami |publisher=offscreen.com |date=March 2001 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> The film's use of overlapping dialogue has influenced the films of [[Robert Altman]] and [[Carol Reed]].<ref name="Cook"/>{{Rp|412}} Reed's films ''[[Odd Man Out]]'', ''[[The Third Man]]'' (in which Welles and Cotten appeared) and ''[[Outcast of the Islands]]'' were also influenced by the film's cinematography.<ref name="Cook"/>{{Rp|425}}

Many directors have listed it as one of the greatest films ever made, including [[Woody Allen]], [[Michael Apted]], [[Les Blank]], [[Kenneth Branagh]], [[Paul Greengrass]], [[Michel Hazanavicius]], [[Michael Mann (director)|Michael Mann]], [[Sam Mendes]], [[Jiri Menzel]], [[Paul Schrader]], [[Martin Scorsese]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=The British Film Institute |location=London, UK |url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/sightandsoundpolls/2012/film/4ce2b6a7a801b |date=2012 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> [[Denys Arcand]], [[Gillian Armstrong]], [[John Boorman]], [[Roger Corman]], [[Alex Cox]], [[Milos Forman]], [[Norman Jewison]], [[Richard Lester]], [[Richard Linklater]], [[Paul Mazursky]], [[Ronald Neame]], [[Sydney Pollack]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/polls/topten/poll/voted.php?film=Citizen%20Kane |title=These critics voted for Citizen Kane (Welles) |publisher=British Film Institute |date=2002 |accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> and [[Stanley Kubrick]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Wrigley |first=Nick |title=Stanley Kubrick, cinephile |publisher=The British Film Institute |location=London, UK |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/polls-surveys/stanley-kubrick-cinephile |date=October 25, 2013 |accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> [[Yasujirō Ozu]] said it was his ===Film memorabilia===
In 1982, film director [[Steven Spielberg]] bought a "Rosebud" sled for $60,500; it was one of three [[balsa]] sleds used in the closing scenes and the only one that was not burned.<ref>{{cite news |title=Newsmakers |publisher=''[[Newsweek]]'' |date=June 21, 1982 |page=51}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/opinion/topics-hidden-treasures-prop-art.html |title=Hidden Treasures: Prop Art |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=June 13, 1982 |accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> After the Spielberg purchase, it was reported that retiree Arthur Bauer claimed to own another "Rosebud" sled.<ref name="Kessler">{{cite news |last=Kessler |first=Robert E. |title=Army retiree claims to have 'Rosebud' |publisher=''[[The Capital Times]]'' (''[[Newsday]]'') |date=June 22, 1982  |accessdate=}}</ref> In early 1942 when Bauer was 12 he won an RKO publicity contest and selected the hardwood sled as his prize.<ref name="christies">{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/citizen-kane-1941-1111427-details.aspx?from=searchresults&pos=54&intObjectID=1111427&sid=de1a8bc4-aec2-4a19-a0e6-5d9d1231e030 |title=Lot 59, Sale 7927 |publisher=[[Christie's]] Los Angeles auction catalogue, ''Film, Television & Pop'' |date=December 15, 1996 |page=31}}</ref> In 1996, Bauer's estate offered the painted pine sled at auction through [[Christie's]].<ref name="christies"/> Bauer's son told CBS News that his mother had once wanted to paint the sled and use it as a plant stand, but Bauer told her to "just save it and put it in the closet."<ref>{{cite news |title=CBS News Transcripts |publisher=''[[CBS]]'' |date=December 14, 1996}}</ref> The sled was sold to an anonymous bidder for $233,500.<ref>{{cite news |title=Clark Gable's Oscar and 'Rosebud' sled sold |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' |date=December 15, 1996}}</ref>

Welles's Oscar for Best Original Screenplay was believed to be lost until it was rediscovered in 1994. It was withdrawn from a 2007 auction at [[Sotheby's]] when bidding failed to reach its estimate of $800,000 to $1.2 million.<ref name="oscarsale"/> Owned by the charitable Dax Foundation,<ref name="oscarsale"/> it was auctioned for $861,542 in 2011 to an anonymous buyer.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/dec/21/orson-welles-citizen-kane-oscar |last=Barnes |first=Henry |title=Welles's "Citizen Kane" Oscar sells for $860,000 |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |location=London |date=December 21, 2011 |accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Mankiewicz's Oscar was sold at least twice, in 1999 and again in 2012, the latest price being $588,455.<ref>{{cite news  |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/29/oscars-auction-sold-citizen-kane_n_1309893.html |title=Oscars Auction: Statuettes from '30s, '40s Sold in Los Angeles|publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]'' (Associated Press) |date=February 29, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref>

In 1989, Mankiewicz's personal copy of the ''Citizen Kane'' script was auctioned at Christie's. The leather-bound volume included the final shooting script and a carbon copy of ''American'' that bore handwritten annotations—purportedly made by Hearst's lawyers, who were said to have obtained it in the manner described by Kael in "[[#"Raising Kane"|Raising Kane]]".<ref>{{cite news  |last=Reif  |first=Rita |date=June 16, 1989 |title=Auctions | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/arts/auctions.html |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=January 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news  |last=McDougall  |first=Dennis |date=June 15, 1989 |title=Between the Lines That Raised 'Kane'| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-15/entertainment/ca-2642_1_charles-foster-kane-herman-j-mankiewicz-citizen-kane |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=January 7, 2015}}</ref> Estimated to bring $70,000 to $90,000,<ref>{{cite news  |date=May 7, 1989 |title=A New Look at 'Kane' | url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1989/05/07/page/395/article/a-new-look-at-kane |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=January 7, 2015}}</ref> it sold for a record $231,000.<ref>{{cite news  |last=Reif  |first=Rita |date=July 2, 1989 |title=Antiques | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/02/books/antiques-books-tell-tales-of-art-and-money.html |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=January 7, 2015}}</ref>

In 2007, Welles's personal copy of the last revised draft of ''Citizen Kane'' before the shooting script was sold at Sotheby's for $97,000.<ref name="oscarsale">{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/12/11/AR2007121101455.html |title='Citizen Kane' Script sells for $97,000 |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |date=December 12, 2007 |accessdate=January 22, 2009}}</ref> A second draft of the script titled ''American'', marked "Mr. Welles' working copy", was auctioned by Sotheby's in 2014 for $164,692.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2014/1000-ways-seeing-l14313/lot.766.html |title=Working draft script for Citizen Kane, here with its original title, 'American' |publisher=''1000 Ways of Seeing: The Private Collection of the late Stanley J. Seeger'', Sotheby's |accessdate=March 11, 2014}}</ref>{{efn|The same item had been sold by Christie's in December 1991, together with a working script from ''The Magnificent Ambersons'', for $11,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/orson-welles-working-scripts-for-2292859-details.aspx?intobjectid=2292859 |title=Orson Welles Working Scripts (Sale 7269, Lot 208) |publisher=Christie's New York, East |accessdate=March 11, 2014}}</ref>}} A collection of 24 pages from a working script found in Welles's personal possessions by his daughter [[Beatrice Welles]] was auctioned in 2014 for $15,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.ha.com/c/item.zx?saleNo=7089&lotNo=46023 |title=An Orson Welles Group of Working Script Pages from Citizen Kane (Lot 46023) |publisher=Entertainment & Music Memorabilia Signature Auction, New York (#7089), Heritage Auctions |accessdate=May 10, 2014}}</ref>

In 2014, a collection of approximately 235 ''Citizen Kane'' stills and production photos that had belonged to Welles was sold at auction for $7,812.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.ha.com/c/item.zx?saleNo=7089&lotNo=46024 |title=An Orson Welles Large Collection of Black and White Film Stills from Citizen Kane (Lot 46024) |publisher=Entertainment & Music Memorabilia Signature Auction, New York (#7089), Heritage Auctions |accessdate=May 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/orson-welles-camera-among-70-items-auction |last=Tang |first=Terry |title=Orson Welles's camera, other items up for auction |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' |date=March 31, 2014 |accessdate=May 11, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512220431/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/orson-welles-camera-among-70-items-auction |archivedate=May 12, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref>

==Rights and home video==
The composited camera negative of ''Citizen Kane'' was destroyed in a New Jersey film laboratory fire in the 1970s. Subsequent prints were derived from a master positive (a fine-grain preservation element) made in the 1940s and originally intended for use in overseas distribution.<ref>{{cite book |last1=McGreevey |first1=Tom |last2=Yeck |first2=Joanne L. |title=Our Movie Heritage |publisher=[[Rutgers University Press]] |location=New Brunswick, NJ |date=1997 |isbn=0-8135-2431-8 |pages=135–36}}</ref> Modern techniques were used to produce a pristine print for a 50th Anniversary theatrical reissue in 1991 which Paramount released for then-owner [[Turner Broadcasting System]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/movies/for-citizen-kane-a-fresh-start-at-50.html |last=Rohter |first=Larry |authorlink=Larry Rohter |title=For 'Citizen Kane,' a Fresh Start at 50 |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=February 20, 1991 |accessdate=}}</ref> which earned $1.6 million in North America.<ref name="Mojo">{{cite web |title=Citizen Kane (1941) |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=citizenkane.htm |date= |accessdate=December 8, 2014}}</ref>

In 1955, RKO sold the American television rights to its film library, including ''Citizen Kane'', to [[C&C Group|C&C Television Corp.]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Boddy |first=William |title=Fifties Television: The Industry and Its Critics |publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]] |location=Champaign, Illinois |date=1993 |accessdate=November 29, 2014 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sWjhCESKy4AC&pg=PA138&q=c%26c%20%2B%20rko%20%2B%201955 |isbn=978-0-252-06299-5}}</ref> In 1960, television rights to the pre-1956 RKO library were acquired by [[United Artists]]. RKO kept the non-broadcast television rights to its library.<ref>{{cite news |last=McCormick |first=Moira |title=RKO Focuses On Upscale Market for Classic Films |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UiQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT75&sqi=2&q=%22rko%20home%20video%22%2B%20%22citizen%20kane%22%2B%201984 |date=August 23, 1986 |page=64}}</ref>

In 1976, when home video was in its infancy, entrepreneur [[Snuff Garrett]] bought cassette rights to the RKO library for what [[United Press International]] termed "a pittance." In 1978 The Nostalgia Merchant released the film through [[Media Home Entertainment]]. By 1980 the 800-title library of The Nostalgia Merchant was earning $2.3 million a year. "Nobody wanted cassettes four years ago," Garrett told UPI. "It wasn't the first time people called me crazy. It was a hobby with me which became big business."<ref>{{cite news |last=Scott |first=Vernon |title=Nostalgia King |publisher=''United Press International'' |date=October 11, 1980}}</ref> RKO Home Video released the film on [[VHS]] and [[Betamax]] in 1985.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/citizen-kane/oclc/016396308 |title=Citizen Kane (Film, 1985) |publisher=[[WorldCat]] |accessdate=May 1, 2012}}</ref>

In 1984, [[The Criterion Collection]] released the film as its [[List of Criterion Collection Laserdisc releases|first]] [[LaserDisc]]. It was made from a fine grain master positive provided by the [[UCLA Film and Television Archive]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.criterion.com/current/posts/840-citizen-kane |last=Smith |first=Roger P. |title=From the Current – ''Citizen Kane'' |publisher=[[The Criterion Collection]]}}</ref> When told about the then-new concept of having an [[audio commentary]] on the disc, Welles was skeptical but said "theoretically, that's good for teaching movies, so long as they don't talk nonsense."<ref name="Lunches"/>{{Rp|283}} In 1992 Criterion released a new 50th Anniversary Edition LaserDisc. This version had an improved transfer and additional special features, including the documentary ''The Legacy of Citizen Kane'' and Welles's early short ''[[The Hearts of Age]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dvduell.de/criterion_website/criterion/catalogpage-58.html |title=Criterion: Citizen Kane: 50th Anniversary Edition |publisher=The Criterion Collection}}</ref>

Turner Broadcasting System acquired broadcast television rights to the RKO library in 1986<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-03-26/business/8601220602_1_turner-broadcasting-system-ua-mgm |title=Turner Acquires MGM/UA |publisher=''Chicago Tribune'' |date=March 26, 1986 |accessdate=}}</ref> and the full worldwide rights to the library in 1987.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-12-10/business/fi-27906_1_rko-movie |title=Turner Buys Rights to 800 RKO Movies |publisher=''Los Angeles Times'' |date=December 10, 1987 |accessdate=}}</ref> The RKO Home Video unit was reorganized into Turner Home Entertainment that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-03-29/entertainment/9201290077_1_old-time-hollywood-studios-turner-label-orson-welles |publisher=''Chicago Tribune'' |title=An OK For RKO |date=March 29, 1992 |accessdate=}}</ref> In 1991 Turner released a 50th Anniversary Edition on VHS and as a collector's edition that includes the film, the documentary ''Reflections On Citizen Kane'', Harlan Lebo's 50th anniversary album, a poster and a copy of the original script.<ref>{{cite news |last=Wilkinson |first=Jack E. |title=VideoView -- UPI Arts & Entertainment; What's new on the home video scene ... |publisher=''United Press International'' |location=Washington D.C. |date=August 29, 1991}}</ref> In 1996, [[Time Warner]] acquired Turner and [[Warner Home Video]] absorbed Turner Home Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-11-14/news/9611150315_1_turner-broadcasting-system-turner-pictures-time-warner |title=Time Warner phasing out Turner Pictures: Time Warner Inc |publisher=''Chicago Tribune'' |date=November 14, 1996 |accessdate=}}</ref> Today, Time Warner's [[Warner Bros.]] unit has distribution rights for the film.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.warnerbros.com/citizenkane/ |title=Citizen Kane |publisher=Warner Brothers}}</ref>

In 2001, Warner Home Video released a 60th Anniversary Collectors Edition [[DVD]]. The two-disc DVD included feature-length commentaries by [[Roger Ebert]] and [[Peter Bogdanovich]], as well as a second DVD with the feature length documentary ''[[The Battle Over Citizen Kane]]'' (1999). It was simultaneously released on VHS.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/citizen-kane/oclc/48011082 |title=Citizen Kane (VHS tape, 2001)  |publisher=WorldCat |accessdate=November 28, 2014}}</ref> The DVD was criticized for being "''too'' bright, ''too clean''; the dirt and grime had been cleared away, but so had a good deal of the texture, the depth, and the sense of film grain."<ref name="Kaplan">{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/dvdextras/2011/09/buy_the_citizen_kane_bluray.html |last=Kaplan |first=Fred |title=Buy the Citizen Kane Blu-ray |publisher=slate.com |date=September 13, 2011 |accessdate=December 7, 2014}}</ref>

In 2003, Welles's daughter Beatrice Welles sued Turner Entertainment, claiming the Welles estate is the legal [[copyright]] holder of the film. She claimed that Welles's deal to terminate his contracts with RKO meant that Turner's copyright of the film was null and void. She also claimed that the estate of Orson Welles was owed 20% of the film's profits if her copyright claim was not upheld. In 2007 she was allowed to proceed with the lawsuit, overturning the 2004 decision in favor of Turner Entertainment on the issue of video rights.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/31/business/fi-kane31 |title=Welles' daughter could get profit from 'Kane' |publisher=''Los Angeles Times'' |accessdate=August 8, 2011}}</ref>

In 2011, it was released on [[Blu-ray]] and DVD in a 70th Anniversary Edition.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/18/movies/new-dvds-citizen-kane-going-places-birth-of-a-nation.html |last=Taylor |first=Charles |title=The New Season DVDs: Movies That Said, 'Look What I Can Do' |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=September 16, 2011 |accessdate=}}</ref> The ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' called it "the Blu-ray release of the year."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/20/PK8B1LGVAR.DTL |last=Johnson |first=G. Allen |title=DVD Review: ''Citizen Kane'' |publisher=''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' (1996) |date=October 23, 2011}}</ref> Supplements included everything available on the 2001 Warner Home Video release, including ''The Battle Over Citizen Kane'' DVD. A 70th Anniversary Ultimate Collector's Edition added a third DVD with ''[[RKO 281]]'' (1999), an award winning [[Television film|TV movie]] about the making of the film. Its packaging extras included a hardcover book and a folio containing mini reproductions of the original souvenir program, lobby cards, and  production memos and correspondence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/50668/citizen-kane/ |last=McQuain |first=Christopher |title=Citizen Kane (Blu-ray) |publisher=[[DVD Talk]] |date=September 7, 2011}}</ref> The transfer for the US releases were scanned as [[4K resolution]] from three different 35mm prints and rectified the quality issues of the 2001 DVD.<ref name="Kaplan"/> The rest of the world continued to receive home video releasees based on the older transfer. This was partially rectified in 2016 with the release of the 75th Anniversary Edition in both the UK and US, which was a straight repackaging of the main disc from the 70th Anniversary Edition.<ref>[http://www.dvdcompare.net/comparisons/film.php?fid=1145 DVDCompare.net: ''Citizen Kane'' (1941) DVD]</ref><ref>[http://www.dvdcompare.net/comparisons/film.php?fid=19703 DVDCompare.net: ''Citizen Kane'' (1941) Blu-ray]</ref>

===Colorization controversy===
In the 1980s, ''Citizen Kane'' became a catalyst in the controversy over the [[film colorization|colorization]] of [[black-and-white]] films. One proponent of film colorization was [[Ted Turner]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/11/04/movies/council-opposes-coloring-old-films.html |last=Molotsky |first=Irwin |title=Council Opposes Coloring Old Films |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=November 4, 1986 |accessdate=January 7, 2014}}</ref> whose Turner Entertainment Company owned the RKO library.<ref>{{cite news |title=TBS acquires rights to RKO film and television library |publisher=''[[Business Wire]]'' |date=December 9, 1987}}</ref> A Turner Entertainment spokesperson initially stated that ''Citizen Kane'' would not be colorized,<ref>{{cite news |last=O'Toole |first=Lawrence |title=No computer coloring for 'Kane' |publisher=''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' |date=December 18, 1987}}</ref> but in July 1988 Turner said, "''Citizen Kane?'' I'm thinking of colorizing it."<ref>{{cite news |last=Bawden |first=James |title=Colorful Turner sees ''Citizen Kane'' in a different light |publisher=''[[Toronto Star]]'' |date=July 28, 1988}}</ref> In early 1989 it was reported that two companies were producing color tests for Turner Entertainment. Criticism increased when filmmaker Henry Jaglom stated that shortly before his death Welles had implored him "don't let Ted Turner deface my movie with his crayons."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1989/Turner-Says-It-s-Testing-To-Colorize-Citizen-Kane-/id-4c23402df90437fb0816882f7e22ff27 |title=Turner Says It's Testing To Colorize 'Citizen Kane' |publisher=''Associated Press'' |date=January 30, 1989 |accessdate=January 5, 2014}}</ref>

In February 1989, Turner Entertainment President Roger Mayer announced that work to colorize the film had been stopped due to provisions in Welles's 1939 contract with RKO that "could be read to prohibit colorization without permission of the Welles estate."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1989/We-ll-Never-Know-If-Rosebud-Was-Red/id-3da27b3969212eb7885db3dbd81b597e |last=Antczyk |first=John |title=We'll Never Know If Rosebud Was Red |publisher=''Associated Press'' |date=February 14, 1989 |accessdate=January 5, 2014}}</ref> Mayer added that Welles's contract was "quite unusual" and "other contracts we have checked out are not like this at all."<ref>{{cite news |title=Turner won't colorize 'Kane' |publisher=''[[United Press International]]'' |date=February 14, 1989 |accessdate=}}</ref> Turner had only colorized the final [[Reel#Motion picture terminology|reel]] of the film before abandoning the project. In 1991 one minute of the colorized test footage was included in the BBC ''[[Arena (UK TV series)|Arena]]'' documentary ''The Complete Citizen Kane''.{{efn| The colorized ''Citizen Kane'' footage appears at approximately 1:17:00.}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wellesnet.com/the-complete-citizen-kane-is-now-online/ |title=The Complete Citizen Kane' documentary is now online |publisher=Wellesnet |date=May 13, 2013 |accessdate=January 1, 2015}}</ref>

The colorization controversy was a factor in the passage of the [[National Film Preservation Act]] in 1988 which created the National Film Registry the following year. [[ABC News]] anchor [[Peter Jennings]] reported that "one major reason for doing this is to require people like the broadcaster Ted Turner, who's been adding color to some movies and re-editing others for television, to put notices on those versions saying that the movies have been altered".<ref>{{cite news |last=Jennings |first=Peter |authorlink=Peter Jennings |title=[[ABC World News|World News Tonight]] |publisher=''[[ABC News]]'' Transcripts, ''[[American Broadcasting Company]]'' |date=September 19, 1989 |accessdate=}}</ref>
